awd_titl_txt: Bilateral NSF/BIO-BBSRC: Synthesis of Microcompartments in Plants for Enhanced Carbon Fixation
awd_abstract_narration:
Demand for food and fuel is steadily increasing and a major challenge in biology is to discover ways to increase crop productivity.  One potential route is by improving photosynthesis. The enzyme Rubisco (ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase) can catalyze the combination of ribulose-1,5-bisphophate with carbon dioxide, but also can catalyze the reaction of ribulose-1,5-bisphophate with oxygen, a process in which previously fixed carbon dioxide is lost. Cyanobacteria and some land plants have mechanisms that concentrate carbon dioxide near the enzyme Rubisco that prevents it from reacting with oxygen, a process called carbon concentrating mechanism.  However, many of the globally important crop plants lack this ability. In this collaborative project investigators from the US (Cornell University) and the UK (Lancaster University and Glasgow University) seek to use newly developed synthetic biology tools to create a carbon concentrating system in a plant that lacks this capability. The project provides interdisciplinary training opportunities, including with their international collaborators, in quantitative and synthetic biology.   

One strategy to improve photosynthetic yields is to replace a crop plant's Rubisco with a faster enzyme along with a carbon-concentrating mechanism. The overall goal of this project is to build the cyanobacterial carbon concentrating mechanism in tobacco as a model system.  This will be accomplished by designing, building, and testing three component parts: 1) engineering a nuclear-encoded bicarbonate transporter onto the chloroplast envelope; 2) removing the chloroplast carbonic anhydrase; and 3) expressing all of the cyanobacterial carboxysome proteins from the chloroplast genome. Biochemical and microscopic studies will be performed to determine the effect of stoichiometry of cyanobacterial proteins on microcompartment size, morphology, and function in carbon concentration and photosynthesis.  Chloroplast transformants will be analyzed to determine the features of the gene regulatory sequences in the synthetic chloroplast operons needed to express proteins in the amounts and ratios needed for assembly of microcompartments.

This collaborative US/UK project is supported by the US National Science Foundation and the UK Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council.

por.por_cntn:
Yields of many major crops are approaching maximal limits possible with traditional breeding.  Nevertheless, further increase remains possible by improved photosynthetic efficiency in plants.  One important step in plant photosynthesis with significant room for improvement is the carboxylation reaction catalyzed by Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (Rubisco). Due to its low rate of carbon fixation, plants invest as much as 25% of leaf nitrogen in Rubisco.  A major drawback of Rubisco is its ability to fix O2 in addition to CO2. This oxygenation reaction results in the energy-intensive process known as photorespiration, which leads to the loss of about 20% of fixed carbon in C3 plants and is projected to escalate further as the global temperature increases.  Cyanobacteria have developed a CO2-concentrating mechanism (CCM) that mitigates the problems of slow enzyme rates and photorespiration. We have investigated the possibility of introducing a CCM from cyanobacteria into chloroplasts through a biotechnological approach.

Cyanobacteria enclose two enzymes, Rubisco and carbonic anhydrase, within micrompartments known as carboxysomes. These bacteria accumulate bicarbonate ion inside the cytoplasm using inorganic carbon transporters. Bicarbonate ion is then converted to CO2 by carbonic anhydrase for efficient CO2 fixation by Rubisco inside carboxysomes.  One requirement for creating a cyanobacterial CCM in plants is the removal of carbonic anhydrase activity from the soluble portion of chloroplasts so that it can be confined to carboxysomes.

We undertook removal of chloroplast carbonic anhydrase (CA) with the use of CRISPR/Cas9 technology.  There are two different CA enzymes in tobacco chloroplasts. When we obtained a double mutant lacking expression of both CA enzymes, we observed that the plants required high carbon dioxide in the atmosphere in order to grow properly.  When growing in normal air, the plants were stunted, leaves were yellow and necrotic, and seeds developed abnormally.  While investigating the reason for the high CO2 requirement, we observed there was no effect of the CA mutations on photosynthesis, breaking a paradigm in the field, which held that chloroplast CA enzymes were important for efficiency of photosynthesis.  Instead, absence of adequate bicarbonate for biosynthetic reactions could explain the mutant phenotypes; high CO2 in the air results in spontaneous production of bicarbonate, that allowing restoration of biosynthesis of needed compounds.  One of the CA proteins is not only an enzyme, but also functions in viral defense in the plant. We discovered that we could make the CA enzyme inactive as an enzyme, but still active in viral defense, allowing future engineering of CA as part of an engineered CCM.

In order to produce the carboxysome structure itself, we generated a number of plants containing multiple genes that encode the protein components of the carboxysome. Upon visualization of the chloroplasts, we noted large structures within chloroplasts that appear to be the initial stages of carboxysome formation.  This finding indicated that further refinement of the ratios of expression of different proteins within the chloroplast will be necessary to produce proper microcompartment structure.  We developed a method termed “Goldbricks” that permits rapid production of multi-gene operons with a variety of gene regulatory sequences in order to fine-tune protein production in future transgenic experiments.

We also observed that plants in which the tobacco large subunit of Rubisco was removed and replaced with the cyanobacterial large subunit of Rubisco were viable despite the absence of the small subunit from cyanobacteria, indicating that a bacterial/plant hybrid enzyme can form that has some functionality, an unexpected result.

The project provided a number of opportunities for training and development of human resources.  A graduate student completed his Ph.D. thesis research on carbonic anhydrase function.  A postdoctoral associate received 4 years of training while learning synthetic biology, photosynthetic kinetics, and plant transformation. A sabbatical visitor from a primarily undergraduate university was able to enhance her cloning and confocal microscopy skills.  Nine undergraduates were able to gain lab experience as a result of the project.  Seven research publications have appeared so far. Results of the projects have been communicated to the public through a press release and two videos available on Youtube.
